description: The Brown Pelican is a large coastal bird with a gray-brown body and a distinctive long bill with a throat pouch used for catching fish. They are commonly seen gliding over the ocean and diving into the water near shorelines.
The Double-crested Cormorant has a dark body, orange facial skin, and a long neck. It is often found near lakes and coastal waters, where it dives underwater to catch fish.
Brandt’s Cormorant is a dark-colored seabird with a long neck and blue throat patch during breeding. They are commonly seen perched on coastal rocks along the Pacific coast.
Pelagic Cormorants are small, slender birds with iridescent greenish-black feathers and thin, hooked bills. They are found near rocky marine cliffs and dive deep to catch fish.

The Surf Scoter is a sea duck with males having black plumage and distinct white patches on the head, while females are dark brown with paler cheeks. These birds are often seen diving in coastal waters.
The Western Grebe is a striking waterbird with a long neck, red eyes, and a sharp yellow bill. They inhabit freshwater lakes and bays, where they are known for their elegant courtship dances.
The Herring Gull is a large gull with pale gray wings, yellow eyes, and pink legs. It is commonly seen along coastlines scavenging for food in a variety of habitats.
The Osprey is a large raptor with a white underside, dark brown wings, and a black eye stripe. It is frequently seen near bodies of water, diving feet-first to catch fish with its sharp talons.
The Least Sandpiper is the smallest shorebird, with brown upperparts, white undersides, and a thin black bill. They forage along muddy shores and wetlands, often in large flocks during migration.
The Surfbird has mottled brown-gray feathers and yellow legs, blending well with rocky coastlines. They are often found searching for invertebrates along wave-battered shores.
The Black Oystercatcher is a striking shorebird with black plumage, a bright orange bill, and pink legs. It is commonly seen on rocky coastlines prying open shellfish.
The Snowy Plover is a small, pale shorebird with sandy brown upperparts and white undersides. They nest on open sandy beaches and rely on camouflage to protect themselves from predators.
The Willet is a tall, gray-brown shorebird with a bold black-and-white wing pattern visible in flight. They inhabit coastal wetlands and beaches where they feed on invertebrates.
The Whimbrel is a large shorebird with a long, down-curved bill and brown-streaked plumage. It is commonly seen along coasts probing sand and mud for crabs and marine worms.
Sanderlings are small, pale shorebirds with black legs and bills, often seen darting along wave edges. They forage in wet sand for tiny crustaceans and insects.
The Black Turnstone is a stocky shorebird with dark plumage and a short, slightly upturned bill. It frequents rocky Pacific shores, flipping over stones and seaweed to find food.
The Caspian Tern is a large, powerful seabird with a white body, black cap, and thick red-orange bill. Found near coasts and estuaries, they dive to catch fish and defend nesting sites aggressively.
Elegant Terns are slender seabirds with pale gray bodies, black caps, and long, thin orange bills. They breed in coastal colonies and feed primarily on small fish like anchovies.
The Royal Tern has a sleek white body, black crest, and bright orange bill. They are social birds found along sandy beaches and estuaries, often nesting in dense colonies.
The Western Gull is a large gull with a white head, dark gray wings, and a thick yellow bill. They are often found along the Pacific coast scavenging beaches, piers, and garbage sites.
California Gulls are medium-sized with gray wings, yellow legs, and a red spot on their lower bill. They are adaptable birds found along beaches, lakes, and urban areas.
Heermann’s Gull is a medium-sized gull with slate-gray plumage, a white head, and a red bill tipped in black. They are often seen following pelicans to steal food along the coast.
